perturbation.original_text: Neither the Franchisor, its Predecessor nor any person listed under Item 2 or an affiliate offering franchises under Franchisor's principal trademark:     (A) has an administrative, criminal or civil action pending against that person alleging: a felony; a violation of a franchise, antitrust or securities law; fraud; embezzlement; fraudulent conversion; misappropriation of property; unfair or deceptive practices; or comparable civil or misdemeanor allegations.
perturbation.changed_text: Neither the Franchisor, its Predecessor nor any person listed under Item 2 or an affiliate offering franchises under Franchisor's principal trademark:     (A) has, to the best of their knowledge, an administrative, criminal or civil action pending against that person alleging: a felony; a violation of a franchise, antitrust or securities law; fraud; embezzlement; fraudulent conversion; misappropriation of property; unfair or deceptive practices; or comparable civil or misdemeanor allegations.
perturbation.explanation: The addition of "to the best of their knowledge" introduces ambiguity regarding the franchisor's responsibility to disclose pending litigation. This weakens the obligation and provides a loophole for non-disclosure, particularly if the franchisor deliberately avoids obtaining complete information. The phrase makes it more difficult to prove non-compliance.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York General Business Law Article 33 Section 683, which requires full and accurate disclosure of material facts in franchise offerings.

perturbation.original_text: (B) has been convicted of a felony or pleaded nolo contendere to a felony charge or, within the ten year period immediately preceding the application for registration, has been convicted of or pleaded nolo contendere to a misdemeanor charge or has been the subject of a civil action alleging: violation of a franchise; anti-fraud or securities law; fraud; embezzlement; fraudulent conversion or misappropriation of property; unfair or deceptive practices; or comparable allegations.
perturbation.changed_text: (B) has been convicted of a felony or pleaded nolo contendere to a felony charge or, within the ten year period immediately preceding the application for registration, may have been convicted of or pleaded nolo contendere to a misdemeanor charge or may have been the subject of a civil action alleging: violation of a franchise; anti-fraud or securities law; fraud; embezzlement; fraudulent conversion or misappropriation of property; unfair or deceptive practices; or comparable allegations.
perturbation.explanation: Replacing "has been convicted" with "may have been convicted" introduces uncertainty regarding the disclosure of past convictions and civil actions. This weakens the franchisor's responsibility for thorough disclosure and could lead to franchisees entering agreements without full knowledge of the franchisor's legal history.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York General Business Law Article 33 Section 683, which requires full and accurate disclosure of material facts in franchise offerings.

perturbation.original_text: Neither the Franchisor, its affiliate, its predecessor, officers, or general partner during the ten year period immediately before the date of the disclosure document: (a) filed as debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code (or any comparable foreign law); (b) obtained a discharge of its debts under the bankruptcy code; or (c) was a principal officer of a company or a general partner in a partnership that either filed as a debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code or that obtained a discharge of its debts under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code during or within one year after the officer or general partner of the Franchisor held this position in the company or partnership.
perturbation.changed_text: Neither the Franchisor, its affiliate, its predecessor, officers, or general partner during the ten year period immediately before the date of the disclosure document: (a) filed as debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code (or any comparable foreign law), only if such filing was deemed material; (b) obtained a discharge of its debts under the bankruptcy code, only if the debts were substantial; or (c) was a principal officer of a company or a general partner in a partnership that either filed as a debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code or that obtained a discharge of its debts under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code during or within one year after the officer or general partner of the Franchisor held this position in the company or partnership, but only if they were aware of such filings.
perturbation.explanation: By adding qualifiers like "only if such filing was deemed material", "only if the debts were substantial" and "only if they were aware of such filings", the franchisor introduces subjectivity and ambiguity into the disclosure requirements regarding bankruptcy filings. These terms are vague and open to interpretation, potentially allowing the franchisor to avoid disclosing relevant bankruptcy information. What constitutes 'material' or 'substantial' is not defined, creating a loophole.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York General Business Law Article 33 Section 683, which requires full and accurate disclosure of material facts in franchise offerings, including information about bankruptcy filings. The added ambiguity allows for subjective interpretations of 'material' and 'substantial', which is not compliant with disclosure requirements.
